headline: Cardinals Beat Mets, 8-7

headline: Correction
summary: Former Manhattan District Attorney Robert Morgenthau seized Egon Schiele's "Portrait of Wally" in 1998. "What Is Lost When Works Are Trophies" (Leisure & Arts, July 27) gave the date of the seizure as 1988.

summary: Pepper...and Salt

summary: Reporter Ilan Brat on what to do, where to eat and where to stay in and near Baraboo, Wis.

headline: Carlyle Closes China Fund
summary: Carlyle Group announced the first closing of its landmark Chinese-currency-denominated fund after raising the equivalent of $350 million from a group of government and private-sector investors led by an arm of the Beijing city government.

headline: Detroit Ballot Won't Have Mayor-School Proposal
summary: In Detroit, the City Council declined to place on the November ballot a proposal that would have given more power over the city's troubled schools  to the mayor.

summary: Carlyle raised the equivalent of $350 million for its landmark Chinese-currency-denominated fund from a group of government and private-sector investors.

headline: Barn Living, Off the Farm
summary: Tour luxury barn-style homes in Sag Harbor, N.Y., Carbondale, Colo., and Austerlitz, N.Y., all listed for under $2.5 million.

headline: Forbes Ranch, Kauai Retreat
summary: The 85-acre ranch owned by the family of Malcolm Forbes is listed for $12 million. Also, a real estate investor in Hawaii asks $40 million for a beachfront property along Kauai's Secret Beach in Kilauea.

headline: Health Bill's New Tax Rules Under Fire
summary: Democrats may water down or repeal new tax-reporting rules that are supposed to raise $16 billion for health-care legislation, facing a chorus of criticism about the rules.

headline: Berlusconi's Party Censures Lower House Speaker
summary: Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi said some of his closest allies have been disciplined by his party because of irreconcilable political rifts.

headline: ONGC Profit Falls 24%
summary: Oil & Natural Gas Corp.'s quarterly profit fell 24% as India's largest oil producer was hit by discounted sales to state-run fuel retailers.

summary: Interpublic' profit surged on better-than-expected revenue as advertising demand grew in the U.S. and internationally across a range of industry sectors.

headline: Barrick Gold's Profit Leaps
summary: Barrick Gold's profit rose nearly 60% on higher prices and production, and the miner raised its dividend.

summary: Genworth Financial swung to a second-quarter profit as the company's decline in payouts outpaced a fall in revenue, but growth in core profit didn't live up to analysts' expectations.

summary: McClatchy reported lower profit and sales for its second quarter, though its ad-revenue slump eased a bit.

summary: An oil spill this week from an underground pipeline connecting the U.S. to Canada has prompted local health officials to call for the evacuation of as many as 50 homes.

summary: Royal Dutch Shell posted a 15% rise in net profit, as oil and gas production rose 5% and cost cutting accelerated.

headline: New Haven Lab Is an Architectural Experiment
summary: The new Park Street Clinical Laboratory in New Haven not only aids medical diagnoses but is a quite visible attempt to heal longstanding physical and psychological rifts in the surrounding community.

summary: BareBurger in Astoria, Queens is dedicated to organic burgers, be they beef, bison or ostrich.

headline: Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea, Innovative Solutions & Support: Biggest Price Gainers (GAP, ISSC)

headline: Program Trading
summary: Program trading in the week ended July 23 amounted to 27.4% of New York Stock Exchange average daily volume of 2.28 billion shares, or 623.3 million program shares traded per day.

headline: Pictures of the Day: July 29
summary: In today's photos, a Pakistani officer assesses a crash scene, immigration advocates march, Rep. Charles Rangel is charged and more.

headline: Stocks: Down Day, Strong July
summary: The Dow industrials fell 30.72 points amid disappointing revenues from utilities and consumer companies. But blue chips remain on track for their best month since July 2009.

headline: Using Their Arms, Then Their Heads
summary: A look at some of the notable former MLB pitchers who went on to manage -- with varying degrees of success.

headline: EU Rejects Appeal for Bud Trademark
summary: Anheuser-Busch InBev won't be allowed to register its Budweiser beer brand as an EU-wide trademark after Europe's highest court rejected the beer giant's appeal.

headline: Judge Dismisses Some Charges Against Ex-Hevesi Aide

summary: Gold futures bounced from near three-month lows, but only slightly, as investors continued to lighten their holdings as the metal has been losing appeal as a refuge amid calming markets.

headline: Asia's Bond Issuers Target Record Year
summary: Expectations that interest rates in the U.S. and Europe will stay ultra-low for many more months has investors sending cash to Asia, where borrowers offer higher rates. This could be the biggest year for foreign-currency bond deals in the region's history, even as yields there drop too.

headline: American Apparel Shares Plunge as Auditor Steps

headline: SK Telecom Gains From Smartphone Boom
summary: The increasing popularity of smartphones has helped Korea's SK Telecom post a 17% increase in its second-quarter net profit.

headline: Geely Gets Approval to Acquire Volvo
summary: China's Geely has been given government approval to move ahead with a deal to acquire Volvo from Ford.

headline: Soaring Koruna Sparks Intervention Jitters
summary: The Czech National Bank could soon take action to tame its soaring currency, analysts warn, after the koruna this week shot to its highest level against the euro since late 2008.

summary: Bunge posted a higher second-quarter profit but cut its outlook as the agribusiness group suffered from tight supplies in the global soybean market.

summary: Second-quarter earnings at bond ratings firm Moody's rose 11%, beating analysts' estimates, as revenue from U.S. operations helped offset weakness in international markets.

headline: Bank of America Commits $10M in Small-Business Grants
summary: Bank of America Corp. pledges the money to nonprofit organizations that lend to small and rural businesses.

headline: European Stocks Edge Lower
summary: European stocks failed to hold on to gains despite a raft of impressive earnings, particularly in the telecommunications sector, as trepidation ahead of data on the U.S. economy due Friday weighed on sentiment.

summary: New Zealand's central bank raised interest rates, but added their pace and extent may be more moderate than it had projected in June.

headline: TSMC Profit Soars 65%
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. second-quarter net profit soared 65%, boosted by strong wafer shipments.

headline: Jobless Claims Fall

summary: Cosmetics company Avon Products said second-quarter profit rose, helped by demand in developing markets, which offset a decline in the U.S.

headline: CME Profit Climbs 22%

headline: A Summer Romance For Bond Issuers
summary: That wasn't much of a slump. Asia's bond issuers are back with a vengeance.

headline: Goodyear Rides Strong Sales

headline: ArcelorMittal Tests Investors' Mettle
summary: The state of supply and demand makes plans by the steelmaker to raise prices 10% this year look somewhat fanciful.

headline: Dear Poor Panasonic Shareholder
summary: Panasonic's previous restructuring efforts don't offer much to hope for.

headline: Setting a Rental Price
summary: A reader in North Carolina seeks to rent out a vacation property and wonders how much to charge. June Fletcher has tips.

headline: Nikkei Falls 0.6%; Shanghai Rises

summary: Indian software exporter HCL Technologies posted a better-than-expected increase in profit for the lateset quarter, on a rise in outsourcing orders.

summary: U.K. Prime Minister David Cameron is on a two-day visit to India, his first trip to the country since taking office. Some snapshots.

headline: Rove: The Missing Word in Our Afghanistan Strategy

headline: Peter Ferrara: Beware the Balanced Budget Deal
summary: Washington's usual formula—tax increases along with benefit cuts—never works.

headline: Fall in Love, Plug the Island

summary: Sprint Nextel's loss widened as overall subscribership fell and the company booked a $302 million tax-related charge.

summary: Bad spending habits like overdrawing a checking account are good for banks, and for technology and marketing companies trying to help them preserve billions of dollars in overdraft fees.

summary: Microsoft, Google and other U.S. tech giants are pushing to streamline Europe's privacy rules in order to offer more remote computing and data-storage services. Some European governments are resisting.

summary: Karl Berger, Rebecca Kilgore and Ted Nash have been making great music for years, but most New Yorkers wouldn't know them to hear them.

summary: State insurance regulators have invited firms to apply to assess potential losses in commercial mortgage-backed securities, as regulators continue to reduce their reliance on the major ratings firms.

summary: Twyla Tharp's Tony-nominated "Come Fly Away" will end its Broadway run Sept. 5.

summary: Morton's the Steakhouse hosted the first ever NYPD vs. FDNY Grill-Off in Brooklyn.

summary: Clowns, trains and mini-golf are among the attractions of this southwest Wisconsin city, the birthplace of the Ringling Bros. Circus.

summary: An independent counsel said New York Gov. David A. Paterson made 'errors of judgment', but should not face criminal charges for witness tampering.

summary: Technology columnist Walter S. Mossberg recommends a netbook or laptop that can be used to check email while traveling, and more.

headline: Empathy Law Isn't in the Bible
summary: ("Worshippers Looking for a Prophet," by Marta H. Mossburg, Taste, July 23)" When it comes to issues of empathy versus law, Hebrew Scripture, the basis of both Judaism and Christianity, is clearly against it.

summary: A Senate bill promoted as a boon to small businesses includes significant tax benefits for large companies, too.

headline: Hooray for the EPA at Gowanus Site
summary: Regarding Julia Vitullo-Martin's "Big Footed by the EPA in Brooklyn" (Cross Country, July 24): The ex post facto and transferrable liability for environmental damage has always bothered me, and Gowanus is no exception.

headline: Journalists Kidnapped in Mexico
summary: The kidnappings are the latest in a string of violent incidents aimed at silencing the press along Mexico's northern border, where drug cartels battle over routes and lucrative local markets.

summary: The distribution of Champions League money could create super-clubs by introducing spending power to one club in an economically minor league.

headline: Above-Standard Fare
summary: With celebrity diners such as Gwen Stefani, a charcuterie and raw bar, and expansive white-table-cloth tables, the Meatpacking District eatery is anything but what the name suggests.

summary: The dollar weakened against the yen after disappointing economic data combined with a lackluster Federal Reserve report on the economy to stoke concerns that the U.S. recovery was losing steam.

summary: Samsung Electronics reported a record profit, but executives said that may have been the peak for the year as pricing pressures are likely to overwhelm sales growth in the second half.

summary: China's powerful Ministry of Railways dismissed foreign concerns about the transfer of technology from foreign companies participating in its high-speed rail building binge.

summary: In customer-satisfaction surveys, cable companies consistently rate lower than fiber-optic and satellite-video providers.

summary: What's News: World-Wide for July 29, 2010

summary: San Jose pizzeria A Slice of New York is a Mecca for East Coast émigrés who are homesick for Big-Apple-style pizza.

headline: Former Squash Player Wants to Keep Game Thriving
summary: The chairman of World-Wide Group, a real estate development firm, says he will match every dollar raised up to $75,000 for the upcoming Hamptons Squash Week, a move to broaden exposure to the sport.

summary: Anna Prior reports on the water quality of the nation's beaches and a survey of how satisfied hotel guests are with their stays.

summary: An independent counsel has concluded that New York Gov. David Paterson should not face criminal charges over a domestic-violence scandal involving a close aide.

summary: Two new studies bolster a shift in thinking about how to revive many cardiac-arrest patients: Don't do mouth-to-mouth resuscitation.
